title: Transform microwell plates with `tidyplate`
text: input xlsx csv formatted specific way: Top left corner must hold name plate. Column names : 1, 2, 3, forth. Row names : , B, C, forth. must empty row plate.

title: Transform microwell plates with `tidyplate`
text: input file xlsx file reads first sheet default. Users can specify sheet using sheet argument xlsx file. Users can also specify variable name column well ids stored (defaults “well”). Please make sure well_id argument match individual plate names input file. Start loading tidyplate: First check input file valid : mentioned , formatting input file important. csv excel template plate type can created using build_plate function: want retrieve names individual plates: Read import file tibble: Conversely, dataframe tibble can re-exported back plate shaped csv xlsx file: information use functions multiple files multi-sheet excel files read vignette("advanced").
code: library(tidyplate) library(tidyplate) file <- system.file("extdata",                      "example_12_well.xlsx",                      package = "tidyplate") check_plate(file) # No error for valid file #> example_12_well.xlsx: OK; Plate type: 12-well  incorrect_file <- system.file("extdata",                               "incorrect_format.csv",                               package = "tidyplate") check_plate(incorrect_file) # Error type displayed #> Error: #> ! Verify row and column ids in incorrect_format.csv. #> ℹ Expected column ids: 1, 2, 3, and so on. #> ℹ Expected row ids: A, B, C, and so on. #> ℹ Use the `build_plate()` function to build an empty template. build_plate(plate_type = 96,              n_plates = 2,              file_type = "xlsx") # default is csv view_plate_names(file) #> [1] "drug"             "cell_line"        "percent_survived" data <- tidy_plate(file) #> Plate type: 12-well head(data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   well  drug      cell_line percent_survived #>   <chr> <chr>     <chr>                <int> #> 1 A01   Neomycin  HEK293                  60 #> 2 A02   Puromycin HEK293                  NA #> 3 A03   Neomycin  Hela                    52 #> 4 A04   Puromycin Hela                    18 #> 5 B01   Neomycin  HEK293                  62 #> 6 B02   Puromycin HEK293                  23 generate_plate(data, well_id = "well", plate_type = 12, file = "plate.csv")

title: Transform Microplate Data into Tibbles
text: Microtiter plates microplates become standard tool analytical research clinical diagnostic testing laboratories. convenient, high-throughput tools organizing tissue culture, PCR tests (HIV/ COVID screening), immunological assays ELISA, RIA FIA. offer many advantages traditional assay formats including reduced sample reagent volumes, increased throughput, ease automation. goal tidyplate help researchers convert different types microplates tibbles can used data analysis. tidyplate accepts xlsx csv files formatted specific way input. tidyplate supports types standard microplate formats namely: 6-well, 12-well, 24-well, 48-well, 96-well, 384-well, 1536-well plates. tidyplate five functions: tidy_plate: Transforms input file (xlsx csv) tibble. generate_plate: Exports tibble plate-shaped csv xlsx file. check_plate: Checks whether input file valid use tidy_plate(). view_plate_names: Returns names/ id(s) plate input file. build_plate: Generates csv xlsx template plate type. figure demonstrates format 12-well plate input file. Colors visualization purposes .

title: Transform Microplate Data into Tibbles
text: install tidyplate CRAN: can install development version tidyplate GitHub :

title: Transform Microplate Data into Tibbles
text: input xlsx csv formatted specific way: Top left corner must hold name plate. Column names : 1, 2, 3, forth. Row names : , B, C, forth. must empty row plate.

title: Transform Microplate Data into Tibbles
text: example shows use tidyplate. input file xlsx file reads first sheet default. Users can specify sheet using sheet argument xlsx file. Users can also specify variable name column well ids stored (defaults “well”). Please make sure well_id argument match individual plate names input file. First check input file valid : mentioned , formatting input file important. csv excel template plate type can created using build_plate function: want retrieve names individual plates: Read import file tibble: Conversely, dataframe tibble can re-exported back plate shaped csv xlsx file: information use functions multiple files multi-sheet excel files read vignette("advanced").
code: library(tidyplate) file <- system.file("extdata",                      "example_12_well.xlsx",                      package = "tidyplate") check_plate(file) # No error for valid file #> example_12_well.xlsx: OK; Plate type: 12-well  incorrect_file <- system.file("extdata",                               "incorrect_format.csv",                               package = "tidyplate") check_plate(incorrect_file) # Error type displayed #> Error: #> ! Verify row and column ids in incorrect_format.csv. #> ℹ Expected column ids: 1, 2, 3, and so on. #> ℹ Expected row ids: A, B, C, and so on. #> ℹ Use the `build_plate()` function to build an empty template. build_plate(plate_type = 96,              n_plates = 2,              file_type = "xlsx") # default is csv view_plate_names(file) #> [1] "drug"             "cell_line"        "percent_survived" data <- tidy_plate(file) #> Plate type: 12-well head(data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   well  drug      cell_line percent_survived #>   <chr> <chr>     <chr>                <int> #> 1 A01   Neomycin  HEK293                  60 #> 2 A02   Puromycin HEK293                  NA #> 3 A03   Neomycin  Hela                    52 #> 4 A04   Puromycin Hela                    18 #> 5 B01   Neomycin  HEK293                  62 #> 6 B02   Puromycin HEK293                  23 generate_plate(data, well_id = "well", plate_type = 12, file = "plate.csv")

what: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
title: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
text: build_plate() helps user build empty csv xlsx file can used template storing plate data. Ensure plate names unique. populated can used input tidy_plate() function.

title: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
code: build_plate(   plate_type = 6,   n_plates = 1,   plate_names = NULL,   file = NULL,   file_type = NULL )

title: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
text: plate_type specific integer (6, 12, 24, 48, 96, 384, 1536) indicating type microwell plate. n_plates positive integer indicating number plates. plate_names character vector unique values assigned plate. length equal value n_plates. file character string naming file. file_type character string output file type. can either csv xlsx file. default csv.

title: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
text: csv xlsx template file.

title: Build a csv or xlsx template for each plate type — build_plate
code: temp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv")  build_plate(plate_type = 6, n_plates = 2, file = temp_file)

title: Generates a microwell plate shaped csv or excel file from tibble or dataframe — generate_plate
text: Dataframes tibbles good visual inspection microwell plate shaped data. generate_plate() helps user transforming dataframe tibble microwell plate data. opposite tidy_plate() plate data.

title: Generates a microwell plate shaped csv or excel file from tibble or dataframe — generate_plate
Generates a microwell plate shaped csv or excel file from tibble or dataframe — generate_plate
text: x dataframe tibble. well_id character string integer points column containing well ids. plate_type specific integer (6, 12, 24, 48, 96, 384, 1536) indicating type microwell plate. file character string filename output file path type exported file. csv xlsx files supported.

title: Generates a microwell plate shaped csv or excel file from tibble or dataframe — generate_plate
text: csv xlsx file.

title: Generates a microwell plate shaped csv or excel file from tibble or dataframe — generate_plate
code: file_path <- system.file("extdata", "tidy_12_well.csv", package = "tidyplate")  tbl <- read.csv(file_path) temp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv")  plate_12 <- generate_plate(tbl,                            well_id = "well",                            plate_type = 12,                            file = temp_file)

title: Reads and transforms microwell plate to a tibble — tidy_plate
code: file_path <- system.file("extdata", "example_12_well.xlsx",   package = "tidyplate" )  data_12 <- tidy_plate(file = file_path) #> Plate type: 12-well  head(data_12) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   well  drug      cell_line percent_survived #>   <chr> <chr>     <chr>                <int> #> 1 A01   Neomycin  HEK293                  60 #> 2 A02   Puromycin HEK293                  NA #> 3 A03   Neomycin  Hela                    52 #> 4 A04   Puromycin Hela                    18 #> 5 B01   Neomycin  HEK293                  62 #> 6 B02   Puromycin HEK293                  23
